key_issues: Abandonment of opposition under Rule 45(2) of the Trade Marks Rule 2017 due to failure to take action within the specified time.
Registration of a device mark under class 32 in respect of non-alcoholic drinks and beverages, aerated water, beer, and porter, syrups for making beverages, and essences.
Opposition to registration of a trademark under Section 21 of the Trade Marks Act 1999.
Filing of evidence in support of opposition under Rule 50(1) of the Trade Marks Rules 2002.
Extension of time for filing evidence in support of opposition and the applicability of Rule 50(1) of the Trade Marks Rules 2002.
Deemed abandonment of opposition under Rule 45(2) of the Trade Marks Rule 2017 and its implications on the registration process.
Appeal under Section 91 of the Trade Marks Act 1999 to the Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB) and subsequent transfer to the High Court due to abolition of IPAB.
Application of the Trade Marks Rules 2002 and the Trade Marks Rule 2017 in the context of opposition and registration proceedings.
Consequences of delay in filing evidence in support of opposition, including the possibility of deemed abandonment.
Interpretation of Rules 45(2) and 50(1) in determining the abandonment of opposition and the filing of evidence, respectively.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Background:**
The case involves an opposition to the registration of a device mark by Respondent 2, filed by Mahesh Gupta (Appellant) on April 15, 2008, under Section 21 of the Trade Marks Act 1999. The opposition was in response to Respondent 2's application for registration of the device mark under Class 32, filed on April 28, 1998. The application covered "non-alcoholic drinks and beverages, aerated water, beer and porter, syrups for making beverages, and essences."

**Legal Issues:**
The primary issue before the court was whether the Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks was correct in treating the Appellant's opposition as abandoned under Rule 45(2) of the Trade Marks Rule 2017. The Appellant had filed evidence in support of the opposition on June 10, 2010, which was after the prescribed time period. The Appellant had also applied for an extension of time to file the evidence, acknowledging a delay of four months.

**Arguments:**
The Appellant argued that the Deputy Registrar erred in applying the 2017 Rules, as the proceedings had commenced under the 2002 Rules. The Appellant contended that the evidence was filed within the extended time period allowed under the 2002 Rules.

The Respondent 2 argued that the Appellant's opposition was indeed abandoned, as the Appellant had failed to file evidence within the prescribed time period.

**Court Findings:**
The court observed that the Deputy Registrar had formally erred in law by applying the 2017 Rules to the proceedings, which had commenced under the 2002 Rules. The court noted that the Appellant had filed evidence in support of the opposition on June 10, 2010, and applied for an extension of time, which was a procedural requirement under the 2002 Rules.

**Decision:**
The court held that the Deputy Registrar's decision to treat the Appellant's opposition as abandoned was incorrect. The court set aside the order dated August 7, 2019, and remanded the matter to the Deputy Registrar to proceed with the opposition proceedings in accordance with the 2002 Rules. The court directed the Deputy Registrar to consider the Appellant's evidence and the Respondent 2's counterstatement, and to decide the matter on its merits.

In summary, the court's decision was based on the procedural error committed by the Deputy Registrar in applying the wrong set of rules to the proceedings. The court's decision allowed the Appellant's opposition to proceed, and the matter was remanded to the Deputy Registrar for further consideration.

I may observe, at the very outset, that the learend Deputy

the application seeking condonation of delay, were all prior to coming 
into force the 2017 Rules; in fact, much prior thereto.  
 
8. 
Rule 1583 of the 2017 Rules, even while repealing the 2002 
Rules, clearly holds that such repeal would be ―without prejudice to 
anything done under such rules before the coming into force of these 
rules‖.  In other words, the repeal of the 2002 Rules by the 2017 Rules 
would, inter alia, be without prejudice to all proceedings which took 
place in the present case, including the filing of the evidence in 
support of the opposition by the appellant which, admittedly, was

under Rule 50(1) of the 2002 Rules.  The repeal of the 2002 Rules by 
the 2017 Rules cannot, therefore, prejudice the applicability of the 
2002 Rules, insofar as the issue of whether the evidence filed by the 
appellant under Rule 50(1) of the 2002 Rules could be taken on 
record, is concerned. 
 
9. 
The dispute has, therefore, to be examined in the light of Rule 
50(1) of the 2002 Rules. What has to be seen, therefore, is whether the 
opposition of the appellant could be treated as having deemed to have 
been abandoned by applying Rule 50(1) of the 2002 Rules.    
 
10. 
A coordinate Single Bench of this Court of Hon’ble Mr. Justice 
Budar Durrez Ahmed, as he then was, has examined this aspect in 
detail in Sunrider Corporation, U.S.A. v. Hindustan Lever Ltd4. The 
relevant passages from the said decision may be reproduced thus: 
 
―8. 
Reading Rule 50, it is clear that the evidence by way of 
affidavit in support of an opposition to the registration of a trade 
mark has to be filed within two months of the service of a copy of 
the counter-statement on the opponent. This period of two months 
is further extendable by a period of one month in the aggregate 
thereafter as the Registrar may on request allow. Clearly, in the 
first instance, the evidence affidavit has to be filed within two 
months of the receipt of a copy of the counter-statement. The 
Registrar may extend this period by a further one month in the 
aggregate if a request for the same is made in time. Sub-rule (2) of 
Rule 50 makes it clear that if an opponent takes no action under 
Sub-rule (1) within the time mentioned therein, he shall be deemed 
to have abandoned his opposition. It is also interesting to note that 
Sub-rule (3) refers to the application for extension of the period of 
one month mentioned in Sub-rule (1). It is also stipulated that such 
an application has to be made in Form TM-56 accompanied by the 
prescribed fee before the expiry of the period of two months 
mentioned therein. So, it is clear that a strict regimen has been 
prescribed for the filing of evidence by way of affidavit in support 
of an opposition. A plain reading of the provisions makes it 
abundantly clear that the evidence has to be filed within two 
                                          
4 (2007) 143 DLT 148 
Digitally Signed By:SUNIL
SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:04.03.2023
16:11:50
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001627

Page 5 of 9    
 
months in the first instance and, if an appropriate application for 
extension of time is made before the expiry of the period of two 
months and if such application is allowed by the Registrar, then 
latest by a further month. In other words, under no circumstances 
can the evidence affidavit be filed beyond the maximum three 
months prescribed under the said rule. In case the opponent has 
not taken steps within the prescribed time, then there is no option 
left with the Registrar but to deem that the opponent has 
abandoned his opposition.‖ 
(Emphasis Supplied) 
 
11. 
Ms. Rajeshwari seeks, however, to distinguish the decision in 
Sunrider4 essentially on two grounds.   She relies, in the first instance, 
on the judgment of a learned Single Judge of the High Court of 
Gujarat in Wyeth Holdings Corpn. v. Controller General of Patents, 
Designs and Trade Marks5 , which holds, in paras 58 to 60 thus: 
―58.  
In view of the nature of the prayer sought for, there is no 
question of any alternative remedy being available to the 
petitioners. Having found the submissions made by the learned 
senior counsel appearing for the petitioners with substance, the 
same are accepted. There is no question of the petition being  
dismissed on the ground of alternative remedy being available. 
59.  
In view of the aforesaid discussion, in view of the settled 
legal position that subordinate legislation cannot travel beyond the 
scope of main legislation and having regard to the provisions 
of Section 131 which provides for extension of time, this Court has 
only two options, either to declare Sub-rule (2) of Rule 50 as ultra 
virus the Act or by employing principle of 'harmonious 
construction', to read Sub-rule (2) of Rule 50 to be a 'directory' one. 
60. 
In the considered opinion of this Court, there is no reason 
much less a compelling reason for which the first option should be 
exercised and the 'Rule' be struck down by holding it to be 
'mandatory'. As against that, it is a well settled position of law that 
principle of 'harmonious construction' should be pressed into 
service and Sub-rule (2) of Rule 50 be read as 'directory'. This 
Court is of the opinion that by declaring Sub-rule (2) of Rule 50, 
'directory', no injustice or prejudice is going to be caused to any 
party. On the contrary, it will be serving the interest of justice. 
Hence, second option is exercised. Sub-rule (2) of Rule 50 is held 
to be 'directory' in nature.‖ 
 
                                          
5 2006 SCC OnLine Guj 620 
Digitally Signed By:SUNIL
SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:04.03.2023
16:11:50

12. 
Wyeth5, she submits, was not noticed in Sunrider4.  
 
13. 
With greatest respect, I am unable to subscribe to the view 
expressed by the High Court of Gujarat in Wyeth5. 
 
14. 
To my mind, the view espoused in para 60 of the decision in 
Wyeth5, if accepted, would amount to no less than re-writing of the 
applicable statutory provisions. Rule 50(1) of the 2002 Rules is even 
more peremptory, in its application, than Rule 48 of the succeeding 
2017 Rules. While providing a period of two months to an opponent 
opposing an application seeking registration of a trade mark file its 
evidence after receipt of the counter-statement of the applicant, Rule 
50(1) empowers the Registrar to extend the said period only upto one 
month, specifically using the words ―not exceeding one month‖. The 
words ―not exceeding one month‖ are mandatory in their import.  The 
learned Registrar could not, therefore, grant extension of more than 
one month beyond the period of two months from the date of service, 
on the opponent opposing the registration of a mark, of a copy of the 
counter statement.  Grant of any further extension would clearly be in 
the teeth of Rule 50(1). 
 
15. 
Rule 50(2) is even clearer in its import.  It states, in 
unambiguous terms, that, if the opponent took no action under Rule 
50(1) within the time period mentioned therein – meaning two months 
extendable by a maximum period of one month – he shall be deemed 
to have abandoned his opposition.  
 
16. 
Deemed abandonment of the opposition, therefore, follows as 
an inexorable statutory sequitur to the failure, on the part of the 
Digitally Signed By:SUNIL
SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:04.03.2023
16:11:50
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001627 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2022 
 
Page 7 of 9    
 
opponent, in filing the evidence in support of the opposition within the 
period envisaged in Rule 50(1).  Deemed abandonment, therefore, 
occurs by operation of the statute. Even sans any judicial or quasi-
judicial order, therefore, if the opponent opposing the application 
seeking grant of the trade mark fails to file its evidence in support of 
the opposition within a maximum of three months from the receipt, by 
it, of the counter-statement of the trade mark applicant, the opposition 
would ipso facto be deemed to be abandoned irrespective of whether 
any order to that effect is, or is not, passed by any judicial or quasi-
judicial forum. 
 
17. 
The view expressed in Wyeth5, if accepted, would amount to 
rendering largely otiose Rule 50(2) of the 2002 Rules. With respect, 
therefore, it is not possible to accept the said view.  
 
18. 
Ms. Rajeshwari also sought to place reliance on Rule 1056 of 
the 2002 Rules read with Section 1317 of the 1999 Act. 
 
19. 
Though these provisions have been considered by the 
coordinate Bench in Sunrider4, Ms. Rajeshwari advances a 
submission which, according to her, was not advanced in Sunrider4 
and was not, therefore, considered.  She draws attention to the 
                                          
6 105. 
Extension of time.— 
(1) An application for extension of time under Section 131 (not being 
a time expressly provided in the Act or prescribed by Rule 79 or by sub-rule (4) of Rule 80 or a time for the 
extension of which provision is made in the rules) shall be made in Form TM-56. 
(2) Upon an application made under sub-rule (1) the Registrar, if satisfied that the circumstances are such as 
to justify the extension of the time applied for, may, subject to the provisions of the rules where a maximum 
time limit is prescribed and subject to such conditions as he may think fit to impose, extend the time and 
notify the parties accordingly and the extension may be granted though the time for doing the act or taking the 
proceeding for which it is applied for has already expired. 
7131.  
Extension of time.— 
(1) If the Registrar is satisfied, on application made to him in the 
prescribed manner and accompanied by the prescribed fee, that there is sufficient cause for extending the time 
for doing any act (not being a time expressly provided in this Act), whether the time so specified has expired 
or not, he may, subject to such conditions as he may think fit to impose, extend the time and inform the 
parties accordingly. 
(2) Nothing in sub-section (1) shall be deemed to require the Registrar to hear the parties before disposing of 
an application for extension of time, and no appeal shall lie from any order of the Registrar under this section. 
 
Digitally Signed By:SUNIL
SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:04.03.2023
16:11:50
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 8 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001627 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2022 
 
Page 8 of 9    
 
parenthesized words in Rule 105(1) reading ―not being a time 
expressly provided in the Act or prescribed by rule 79 or by sub-rule 
(4) of rule 80 or a time for the extension of which provision is made in 
the rules‖. According to Ms. Rajeshwari, the import of the afore-
extracted parenthesized words in Rule 105(1) was to restrict the 
inflexibility of the provision only to cases where the time was 
provided in the Act or prescribed by Rule 79 or Rule 80(4).   
 
20. 
The submission is obviously unacceptable, as the parentheses 
also include the words ―or a time for the extension of which provision 
is made in the rules‖. As already noted, Rule 50(1) provides for 
extension of time and curtails the maximum period by which such 
extension could be granted to one month.  The provision for extension 
of time as contained in Rule 50(1), therefore, rules out the 
applicability of Rule 105 to the facts of the present case.  
 
21. 
On all other aspects, the coordinate Bench in Sunrider4, having 
examined the issue in law in detail, this Bench does not deem it 
necessary to reinvent the wheel. I express my respectful concurrence 
with the views expressed in the passages from Sunrider4 extracted 
hereinabove which, unfortunately for the appellant, cover the case 
against it on all fours.  
 
22. 
I see no reason, therefore, to differ with the ultimate decision, of 
the Deputy Registrar, to deem the opposition of the appellant as 
having been abandoned.  The deemed abandonment would, however, 
be under Rule 50(1) of the 2002 Rules, and not Rule 45(1) of the 2017 
Rules.  
 
Digitally Signed By:SUNIL
SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:04.03.2023
16:11:50
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 9 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001627 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2022 
 
Page 9 of 9    
 
23. 
Subject to that modification, the impugned order dated 7th 
August 2019 is, therefore, upheld.  
 
24. 
The appeal is dismissed. 
 
 
 
C. HARI SHANKAR, J.

According to the PDF document "Mahesh Gupta v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the case involves an appeal filed by Mahesh Gupta against the Registrar of Trade Marks and another respondent. The appeal is related to the registration of a device mark under class 32 for non-alcoholic drinks and beverages. The respondent 2 filed the application for registration on April 28, 1998, and the appellant filed an opposition on September 15, 2006.

The appellant filed evidence in support of the opposition on June 10, 2010, and applied for an extension of time on June 11, 2010. However, the Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks held the opposition to be deemed abandoned under Rule 45(2) of the Trade Marks Rule 2017 on August 7, 2019.

The appellant preferred an appeal under Section 91 of the Trade Marks Act before the Intellectual Property Appellate Board, which was later transferred to the High Court of Delhi due to the abolition of the IPAB by the Tribunals Reforms Act 2021. The appeal was heard by Hon'ble Mr. Justice C. Hari Shankar on March 2, 2023. The parties were represented by their respective counsels, Ms. Rajeshwari H. and Ms. Swathi Sukumar.

Key dates mentioned in the document include April 28, 1998, September 15, 2006, June 10, 2010, June 11, 2010, August 7, 2019, and March 2, 2023. The document does not mention any specific amounts. The case is related to trade mark registration and opposition proceedings. (Source: Mahesh Gupta v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf)

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Mahesh Gupta v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the case involves an appeal by Mahesh Gupta against the decision of the Registrar of Trade Marks to treat his opposition to a trademark registration as abandoned. The dispute is examined under the Trade Marks Rules, 2002, which were in force at the time of the initial proceedings. 

The court notes that the learned Deputy Registrar erred in law by passing the impugned order under the 2017 Rules, which repealed the 2002 Rules. The repeal does not prejudice the applicability of the 2002 Rules in this case, particularly with regards to the filing of evidence under Rule 50(1) of the 2002 Rules.

The court relies on a previous decision by Hon'ble Mr. Justice Budar Durrez Ahmed in Sunrider Corporation, U.S.A. v. Hindustan Lever Ltd, which examined the provisions of Rule 50 of the 2002 Rules. The rule states that evidence in support of an opposition must be filed within two months of the service of a copy of the counter-statement, with a possible extension of one month.

The key issue is whether the appellant's opposition can be deemed abandoned under Rule 50(1) of the 2002 Rules. The court must determine whether the learned Deputy Registrar was correct in treating the appellant's opposition as abandoned. The case is currently before the High Court of Delhi, with the appellant represented by Ms. Rajeshwari H. and Ms. Swapnil Gaur, and the respondents represented by Ms. Swathi Sukumar, Mr. Naveen Nagarjuna, Mr. Pratyush Rao, and Mr. Ritik Raghuvanshi. (Source: Mahesh Gupta v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf)

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
The legal document section from the PDF "Mahesh Gupta v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf" discusses the case C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2022 in the High Court of Delhi. The appellant, Mahesh Gupta, is represented by Ms. Rajeshwari H. and Ms. Swapnil Gaur, while the respondents, Registrar of Trade Marks and another, are represented by Ms. Swathi Sukumar, Mr. Naveen Nagarjuna, Mr. Pratyush Rao, and Mr. Ritik Raghuvanshi.

The legal argument revolves around the interpretation of Rule 50(1) of the 2002 Rules, which prescribes a time limit for filing evidence in opposition to a trade mark registration application. The rule states that the evidence affidavit can be filed within two months, extendable by one month, making it a maximum of three months.

Ms. Rajeshwari H. attempts to distinguish the decision in Sunrider, relying on the judgment of the High Court of Gujarat in Wyeth Holdings Corpn. v. Controller General of Patents, Designs and Trade Marks, which held that Sub-rule (2) of Rule 50 is "directory" in nature. However, the court rejects this view, stating that accepting it would amount to re-writing the applicable statutory provisions. The court affirms that the words "not exceeding one month" in Rule 50(1) are mandatory, and any further extension would be in contravention of the rule.

The PDF document, "Mahesh Gupta v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", provides the context for this legal proceeding, which includes the Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/001627, and the date of signing, 04.03.2023. The case highlights the importance of adhering to statutory time limits in legal proceedings.

nodes.title: Page 5
nodes.summary:
According to page 5 of the PDF "32. Mahesh Gupta v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the court discusses the timeline for filing evidence affidavits in trademark opposition cases. The rule prescribes a maximum of three months for filing, with an initial two-month period and a possible one-month extension. 

Ms. Rajeshwari, the appellant's counsel, cites a Gujarat High Court judgment (Wyeth Holdings Corpn. v. Controller General of Patents, Designs and Trade Marks) to argue that Sub-rule (2) of Rule 50 should be considered "directory" rather than "mandatory". This means that the rule should be interpreted flexibly to serve the interest of justice, rather than being strictly adhered to. The Gujarat High Court judgment supports this interpretation, stating that declaring the rule as "directory" would not cause injustice or prejudice to any party. (Source: PDF page 5)

extension of time is made before the expiry of the period of two 
months and if such application is allowed by the Registrar, then 
latest by a further month. In other words, under no circumstances 
can the evidence affidavit be filed beyond the maximum three 
months prescribed under the said rule. In case the opponent has 
not taken steps within the prescribed time, then there is no option 
left with the Registrar but to deem that the opponent has 
abandoned his opposition.‖ 
(Emphasis Supplied) 
 
11. 
Ms. Rajeshwari seeks, however, to distinguish the decision in 
Sunrider4 essentially on two grounds.   She relies, in the first instance, 
on the judgment of a learned Single Judge of the High Court of 
Gujarat in Wyeth Holdings Corpn. v. Controller General of Patents, 
Designs and Trade Marks5 , which holds, in paras 58 to 60 thus: 
―58.  
In view of the nature of the prayer sought for, there is no 
question of any alternative remedy being available to the 
petitioners. Having found the submissions made by the learned 
senior counsel appearing for the petitioners with substance, the 
same are accepted. There is no question of the petition being  
dismissed on the ground of alternative remedy being available. 
59.  
In view of the aforesaid discussion, in view of the settled 
legal position that subordinate legislation cannot travel beyond the 
scope of main legislation and having regard to the provisions 
of Section 131 which provides for extension of time, this Court has 
only two options, either to declare Sub-rule (2) of Rule 50 as ultra 
virus the Act or by employing principle of 'harmonious 
construction', to read Sub-rule (2) of Rule 50 to be a 'directory' one. 
60. 
In the considered opinion of this Court, there is no reason 
much less a compelling reason for which the first option should be 
exercised and the 'Rule' be struck down by holding it to be 
'mandatory'. As against that, it is a well settled position of law that 
principle of 'harmonious construction' should be pressed into 
service and Sub-rule (2) of Rule 50 be read as 'directory'. This 
Court is of the opinion that by declaring Sub-rule (2) of Rule 50, 
'directory', no injustice or prejudice is going to be caused to any 
party. On the contrary, it will be serving the interest of justice. 
Hence, second option is exercised. Sub-rule (2) of Rule 50 is held 
to be 'directory' in nature.‖

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary: According to page 6 of the PDF "32. Mahesh Gupta v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the court discusses the interpretation of Rule 50(1) of the 2002 Rules. The judge disagrees with the view expressed in Wyeth, stating that the rule is peremptory and only allows for a one-month extension. The judge argues that granting an extension beyond this period would be against the rule. Rule 50(2) is cited, which states that if the opponent takes no action within the specified time period, they shall be deemed to have abandoned their opposition. The court emphasizes that this abandonment is a statutory consequence of failing to act within the given time frame. The case is C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2022, with Mahesh Gupta as the appellant and the Registrar of Trade Marks as the respondent. The decision was signed by Sunil Singh Negi on March 4, 2023.

12. 
Wyeth5, she submits, was not noticed in Sunrider4.  
 
13. 
With greatest respect, I am unable to subscribe to the view 
expressed by the High Court of Gujarat in Wyeth5. 
 
14. 
To my mind, the view espoused in para 60 of the decision in 
Wyeth5, if accepted, would amount to no less than re-writing of the 
applicable statutory provisions. Rule 50(1) of the 2002 Rules is even 
more peremptory, in its application, than Rule 48 of the succeeding 
2017 Rules. While providing a period of two months to an opponent 
opposing an application seeking registration of a trade mark file its 
evidence after receipt of the counter-statement of the applicant, Rule 
50(1) empowers the Registrar to extend the said period only upto one 
month, specifically using the words ―not exceeding one month‖. The 
words ―not exceeding one month‖ are mandatory in their import.  The 
learned Registrar could not, therefore, grant extension of more than 
one month beyond the period of two months from the date of service, 
on the opponent opposing the registration of a mark, of a copy of the 
counter statement.  Grant of any further extension would clearly be in 
the teeth of Rule 50(1). 
 
15. 
Rule 50(2) is even clearer in its import.  It states, in 
unambiguous terms, that, if the opponent took no action under Rule 
50(1) within the time period mentioned therein – meaning two months 
extendable by a maximum period of one month – he shall be deemed 
to have abandoned his opposition.  
 
16. 
Deemed abandonment of the opposition, therefore, follows as 
an inexorable statutory sequitur to the failure, on the part of the

nodes.summary: According to page 7 of the PDF "32. Mahesh Gupta v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the court discusses the deemed abandonment of a trade mark opposition. If the opponent fails to file evidence in support of the opposition within three months from the receipt of the counter-statement, the opposition is deemed abandoned by operation of the statute. The court rejects the view that an order is required for deemed abandonment, citing Rule 50(1) of the 2002 Rules. The court also considers Rule 105 and Section 131 of the 1999 Act, which allow for the extension of time, but notes that this does not support the opponent's argument. The case is Mahesh Gupta v. Registrar of Trade Marks, with Neutral Citation Number 2023/DHC/001627.

period envisaged in Rule 50(1).  Deemed abandonment, therefore, 
occurs by operation of the statute. Even sans any judicial or quasi-
judicial order, therefore, if the opponent opposing the application 
seeking grant of the trade mark fails to file its evidence in support of 
the opposition within a maximum of three months from the receipt, by 
it, of the counter-statement of the trade mark applicant, the opposition 
would ipso facto be deemed to be abandoned irrespective of whether 
any order to that effect is, or is not, passed by any judicial or quasi-

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Mahesh Gupta v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", a legal proceeding took place in the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi (Case No. C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2022 & I.A. 4245/2023). The appellant, Mahesh Gupta, was represented by Ms. Rajeshwari H. and Ms. Swapnil Gaur, while the respondents, Registrar of Trade Marks and another, were represented by Ms. Swathi Sukumar, Mr. Naveen Nagarjuna, Mr. Pratyush Rao, and Mr. Ritik Raghuvanshi.

The court decision, dated March 2, 2023, and digitally signed on March 4, 2023, upheld the impugned order dated August 7, 2019. The appeal was dismissed, and the opposition of the appellant was deemed abandoned under Rule 50(1) of the 2002 Rules, not Rule 45(1) of the 2017 Rules.

The court rejected the appellant's submission that Rule 105(1) allowed for flexibility in the time provision, citing that the rule's parenthesized words restrict its applicability. The judge concurred with the views expressed in a previous case, Sunrider, which covered the issue in detail. The decision was made by C. Hari Shankar, J., with a neutral citation number of 2023/DHC/001627. The PDF document provides the full text of the court decision, including the arguments, facts, and decisions. (Source: Mahesh Gupta v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf)

nodes.title: Page 8
nodes.summary: According to page 8 of the PDF "32. Mahesh Gupta v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf", the court discusses the applicability of Rule 105 to the case. The appellant's counsel, Ms. Rajeshwari, argues that the rule only restricts inflexibility to cases where time is provided in the Act or prescribed by Rule 79 or Rule 80(4). However, the court rejects this argument, citing the inclusion of "or a time for the extension of which provision is made in the rules" in the parenthesized words. The court references Rule 50(1), which provides for extension of time, and rules out the applicability of Rule 105. The court ultimately upholds the Deputy Registrar's decision to deem the opposition abandoned under Rule 50(1) of the 2002 Rules. The judgment was signed by Sunil Singh Negi on March 4, 2023. (Source: "32. Mahesh Gupta v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf")

parenthesized words in Rule 105(1) reading ―not being a time 
expressly provided in the Act or prescribed by rule 79 or by sub-rule 
(4) of rule 80 or a time for the extension of which provision is made in 
the rules‖. According to Ms. Rajeshwari, the import of the afore-
extracted parenthesized words in Rule 105(1) was to restrict the 
inflexibility of the provision only to cases where the time was 
provided in the Act or prescribed by Rule 79 or Rule 80(4).   
 
20. 
The submission is obviously unacceptable, as the parentheses 
also include the words ―or a time for the extension of which provision 
is made in the rules‖. As already noted, Rule 50(1) provides for 
extension of time and curtails the maximum period by which such 
extension could be granted to one month.  The provision for extension 
of time as contained in Rule 50(1), therefore, rules out the 
applicability of Rule 105 to the facts of the present case.  
 
21. 
On all other aspects, the coordinate Bench in Sunrider4, having 
examined the issue in law in detail, this Bench does not deem it 
necessary to reinvent the wheel. I express my respectful concurrence 
with the views expressed in the passages from Sunrider4 extracted 
hereinabove which, unfortunately for the appellant, cover the case 
against it on all fours.  
 
22. 
I see no reason, therefore, to differ with the ultimate decision, of 
the Deputy Registrar, to deem the opposition of the appellant as 
having been abandoned.  The deemed abandonment would, however, 
be under Rule 50(1) of the 2002 Rules, and not Rule 45(1) of the 2017 
Rules.
